Our almost 3 year old, Sophie, entered the world of "big kids" when she fell down the stairs last night. If you're not a parent, you won't understand how sickening the sound is of hearing your kid wallop against a wooden stair, to be followed by some mighty loud crying and wailing. Her limbs were intact and the tears were plenty, with a big colored bump on one side of her noggin, so we opted to be safe and took her into the urlLink U of M Emergency Room . "Did she black out? Any vomiting?" Nothing funky going on with this tough toddler, so after being checked out by the doc, we headed home back for stories and some healthy "Couple more minutes!" before finally getting her and Madeline to bed. Sophie, new rules for you when on the stairs: No more bare socks when on the stairs. You have slippers...wear 'em. No more twenty-seven items carried down the stairs from your bedroom...try and find the living room floor and see if there's any room for it all. You have your sister have now reached kid quota for tumbling on the stairs...next time try a magic carpet ride. -chris

Ever pay a bill online? Your phone bill, maybe a credit card, even your mortgage, can probably be paid online. I pay many of our bills online, yet today, I hit Comcast's web site, hoping to pay my cable/net access bill, and what do I get? I am able to find out how much I owe, but then I'm directed to DROP MY PAYMENT OFF at a payment center. Hello? This is the company that's been spewing for more than a few years about how the "future is broadband, blah blah blah." I call 'em up, ask about paying my bill online and I get "You may pay your bill over the phone if you'd like." That's well and dandy, but I don't want to talk to a human when I pay my cable bill. I want to fire up a web browser, hit the payment site, enter some numbers, and, like magic, pay for another month of ToonDisney, Noggin and the like. -chris

urlLink France backs school head scarf ban Hmmmm...what is going on in France? Are they having problems in some of their schools that are prompting parents to ask for the banning of scarves, so students can focus on learning and not have to worry about getting beat up because of an item of clothing? No. The French National Assembly has approved a ban on "conspicuous" religious symbols in French schools, with the focus of the attention on banning Muslim headscarves in school. France, paraniod? Imagine if the United States Congress passed a similar ban; no head scarves, no yamakas, etc. Speeches from across the world would condemn the US as being a bastion of hate and fear mongering, of forcing children and their families to compromise their religious values. Earth to France. Get over yourselves and enjoy a Big Gulp, on us.

It's nice to see that NASCAR takes its image and growing popularity seriously, especially when it comes to shaking that southern, good ole boy image that so many people choose to apply to stock car racing. Case in point: One Jimmy Spencer, a veteran of the Nextel Cup and ambassador of the sport, chose to welcome Toyota's entry in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck series for 2004 by uttering the neighborly words "They bombed Pearl Harbor, don't forget." NASCAR's response? "That's Jimmy Spencer." This is the same sanctioning body that chose to deal with Tony Stewart's tirades by having him attend anger management classes. For Toyota's sake, I hope their teams and drivers pound the snot out of the competition in the Craftsman Truck series, in the same way they've pounded the competition in the dealer showrooms. Oh, and Jimmy, Pat Buchanan called...still no sign of sponsor dollars for 2004.

Condoleezza Rice, the National security advisor to Dubya, will FINALLY meet with the 9/11 commission on Thursday, in PUBLIC. Ms. Rice is employed by the same White House that saw fit to thrust her in front of every Sunday morning talk show in an effort to discredit former White House counterterrorism chief Richard Clarke. The same White House that tried to use the separation of powers to explain away why Rice should not have to testify publicly. The same Rice that appeared on Face the Nation, 60 Minutes, penned an item for the Washington Post, spoke to seemingly any interviewer within camera range; but somehow she still saw fit to stuck to her guns that she should not speak publicly with the very commission investigating possible intelligence failures surrounding the 9/11 attacks. Me thinks the MTV generation has hit the White House. Condoleezza Rice is comfortable speaking to America on her terms, but she is seemingly dumbstruck that the same public that voted her boss' administration into office would ask her to speak to them on their terms. welcome to the big time. Rice, Rice, baby...

Lots of set changes, many dancers, elaborate routines, and, unfortunately, for me, more of Madonna infusing her political/social schtick amongst an arrangement of songs that are best enjoyed without being tied to recent news headlines. Ignoring the political stuff (Madonna, stay out of movies and don't run for office), the show, it's not a concert, was very well done. On our drive back home, Lisa remarked that we seem to be on an 80's music reunion tour, having attended Duran Duran back in the Fall and Prince earlier this summer, along with Madonna. Can the impossible happen next? Will The Police re-unite, so I can finally see them live?

I did some grocery shopping yesterday. This evening I'm preparing a snack of chips and salsa. I open my fridge and locate the jar of salsa. For some reason, I check the expiration date on the jar of salsa. The salsa expires on November 12, 2005. That jar of salsa could have sat on the grocery story shelf until November 11, 2005!!!! And I still could have served it up at a party on November 12, 2005. Should I thank NASA? Will Greenpeace protest?
